She has had 2 beautiful children along the way.  Lots of ups and downs so be strong for your girl. She participates on this cancer board geared towards young woman. if you haven't been there yet, try it they may also have some answers for you. http://www.youngsurvival.org/bulletin-board/
Posts.Title: where to go from here worriedbf PghGrl99

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 08:39PM - edited Jun 11, 2009 08:48PM by ghety Although I bought alot of zip up tops, the things I wore most often were very soft stretchy t'shirts or sleep Ts with a deep v-neck. Because they were so stretchy and the necks wide enough, it really wasn't a struggle to get into them. They felt so good next to my reconstructed body ;). (I hope this doesn't sound gross, but I would stick a mini-pad to the inside of the t-shirt to absorb some of the oozing that was going on at the incision sites) For my doctor's appointments I had a great little LLBEAN zip front jacket/top (activewear) with pouches inside to hide my drains while in the waiting room.

Posts.Title: Would you get MRI ini my situation ghety ghety

Posts.Content: ghety wrote: I was dx in October with DCIS high grade. I have chosen to do bi-lat mastectomy with tram free flap. Looks like I will have to wait until January for breast surgeon and PS to combine their schedules. Dr. suggested MRI to make sure more is not going on since we have to wait another month, or do the node biopsies in advance. Unfortunately i have to consider the financial side of all this. Doing the MRI will cost me the last $600 of my out of pocket expenses this year before things are covered in full and then I start all over again with meeting my $1500 ded/out of pocket in January. Trying to choose MRI over SNB. Will MRI provide info about lymph node involvement? Since I am having the bilat, my tissue will be tested in January when it is removed. SO confused, I am ready to call for the MRI but don't know if it will be that much of a help. When I left my last appt I had nixed the MRI and asked to do nodes if possible. I figured I would be getting the nodes done anyway (at time of bilat) so I may as well get one thing out of the way and start healing before the big surgery. Major second guessing on here. Help?? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 09:59AM ghety wrote: HI Tara, I don't understand alot of what you have been through (lots of big words in there I have never seen before), but I do know about mastectomy and tram flap reconstruction. Even though I had stage 0 DCIS, i chose mastectomy. I just wanted to increase my chances of saying goodbye to cancer for as long as possible. Flap procedures have a longer recovery time (and longer operation) but mine turned out great. Although it was just 8 weeks ago, I am very happy with the new breasts, they seem quite real. So if you have any questions about muscle-sparing tram flaps feel free to PM me. So sorry you didn't get any answers before. I hope you are coping well. All my best to you as you proceed.
Posts.Title: Surgery - Finally taraleec Stumped

Posts.Content: ghety wrote: I am a bit premature asking this question because I don't have biopsy report in my hands yet. But, is it possible for a biopsy to completely miss a lump? This lump is very characteristic of a fibroadenoma, therefore, it moves alot. We got a verbal report of benign, but the tissue sample may have been of just breast tissue not the lump (if I understood correctly). This is in regard to my 21 yr old daughter and now we are going to get it completely removed - which is what we wanted to do in the first place so I am glad about that. But it leaves me wondering if the lump was completely missed, therefore B9 means nothing. Anyone have this happen? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 07:12PM ghety wrote: I am 47. Diagnosed 3 weeks ago with DCIS (non-invasive). Chose not to do lumpectomy and go with Bi-lat with immediate reconstruction. I have watched a sister -in- law deal with breast cancer for 15 years. Her first lump was treated with lumpectomy, radiation and chemo. 6 years later she chose bi-lat when a new lump showed up. Her biggest obstacle was complications from a tram flap done on the previously radiated side. Radiation had really affected the tissue on that side and infection complicated things. With all that she has been through that is her biggest complaint. The non radiated side got an implant and is great. She has 2 little girls and has just found out she is now in stage 4 metastatic cancer to the liver. I don't know if a lumpectomy will "cure" my cancer. My feeling is probably not (my mother is a bc survivor too). So I wanted to avoid radiating my tissue and just go for it (the bilat) while my chances of getting great new foobs is still possible ;)

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 03:03PM ghety wrote: Hi JL, I had a bilat mx with recon 1/28/09. I am feeling so much of what you described too. My torso just doesn't want to cooperate. Can't sleep in a bed yet because it hurts too much to shift and roll over and such. I just started driving again this week but like you said turning is very uncomfortable. I can't stand to have a bra on. Sometimes I will tie a thin knit scarf under my breast line and it sort of takes some of the uncomfortableness away from my chest area. While I can't relate to the missing breasts since I had a tram, I just feel like so many other woman on here seem to be feeling so good by 6 or 7 weeks, and one can't help but wonder if something is wrong when the relief doesn't come. I want my arms to work better and I just want to feel good again. I hope the same for you and I hope it comes soon. All my best to you and I hope the rope isn't anything serious or long term. Yay yay yay though, about the cancer free part! Carole

Posts.Title: Back home - what will I need help with? ghety ghety

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 09:41AM ghety wrote: I had a 20 year old studying abroad, 18 year old a freshmen in college. I waited until I had the biopsy report and knew the course of acton I would take. I gathered as much information as I could so that I was equipped to answer their questions. I knew that they would want to be reassured that I would be OK. I will admit I painted as pretty a picture as possible, I just didn't see the need to cause any extra worry for them. I saved all the difficult emotional stuff to share with my husband, which is what I do with most things that go on in our lives.
Posts.Title: When to tell daughter away in college Eliza2009 murphmort

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 09:40PM ghety wrote: Can't help much, but can give my experience. No calcifications is probably good. Calcifications are where my cancer was found (no lump, just calcifications).  My 21 year old daughter had a lump removed this summer and it was 3.2cm, so 1.6 probably not so big. Hers was considered to be to fibrocystic or fibroadenoma. It could be felt. It was oval and slippery. The first biopsy revealed just breast tissue so we weren't even sure that the lump was part of the sample (it moved very easily). We insisted on an excisional biopsy (I couldn't bear not knowing for sure- I wanted that lump in a jar!) and that revealed fibroadenoma. She was told she has very fibrous breasts and may have more lumps to deal with later.  Hopefully yours is a similar situation and all will be b9. Hang in there!

Posts.Title: 100 things never to say to a woman who has had a mastectomy: iwannabefree jillyG

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 06:33PM - edited Apr 20, 2009 06:34PM by ghety Hi Jen! I had a tram 12 weeks ago. I had drains in for 4-5 weeks and after they came out I developed a seroma. Didn't know that was what it was at the time though. My lower abdomen filled up like a big 'ol water balloon. You touched it and it rolled in waves out to the sides. I went weekly to have it drained with a very large syringe. The first few weeks they extracted several syringes full (around 300cc). It has slowed down alot and it has been 2 weeks since my last needle draining (which was only about 60 cc). I go on Thursday again but I think it has pretty much stopped. Wearing the binder helped alot with holding down the volume as well as the weird sensation I felt through the tummy. The first 3 times I never felt the needle, the last time I went I definitely felt the pinch of the needle so I hope I am done with that now. The doctor spoke of possibly re-inserting drain if he sees more fluid on this upcoming visit so I am glad that it has really slowed down. Best of luck to you and try the binder!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 09:37AM ghety wrote: Its so hard to get a grasp on the whole scope of what is about to happen. I chose to do the bilat mx / tram recon and knew I would not change my mind. I had the freakout/sadness attack. Within a few days I became accustomed to all the new incisions and drains. Immediate recon helped but it is a SLOW recovery. 8 weeks out (and still uncomfortable) I have grown to really like the "new" me. It represents the brave, proactive, no nonsense "new" me. You'll be OK, you will still be you. Many good wishes being sent your way for a successful surgery, quick recovery, and peace of mind!
